item.title: Comment on Why I don’t think the USG will default by carlospln
item.description:
Shorter Cowen: It's never defaulted, so it never will.

The US military is a toothless tiger, albeit one with a Brobdingnagian expense line. It hasn't won a war since Nagasaki. See the effectiveness of Operation Prosperity Guardian-it can't even beat a band of Stone Age Houthis.

It's status of having the world's reserve currency is eroding, as more & more countries transact in their own, or in renmimbi, thanks to your idiotic US President's sanctions on Russian CH4.

Last, you are adding $1 Trillion to your federal budget deficit every 90 days.

https://www.usdebtclock.org/

Throw another log on the fire!

item.title: Comment on Saturday assorted links by jimmy
item.description:
#2. Little bit disappointed that this article keeps referring to their project as an artificial synapse, when it doesn't resemble at all the neurotransmitter/chemical synapse which is what most people are usually referring to when they talk about synapses.
It may be a good model of an *electrical* synapse, but that is not the typical synapse in grown mammals, and not what people are usually referring to when they talk about synapses and synaptic learning etc.
Don't get me wrong, I think this is a really cool, but I'm a little disappointed by the lack of clarity, especially considering this is from a scientific news publication rather than a general news source.

item.title: Comment on Saturday assorted links by RAD
item.description:
7. WSJ Ethan Mollick profile.

Also, Meet [Sanja Fudler] Nvidia's Canadian secret weapon — Financial Post:

But generative AI has been Fidler and Co.’s “bread and butter” at the lab since day one. And what has her jazzed and a wee bit stressed these days is whether she and her team can push the machine-learning boundaries to a place where, say, you type a word and AI renders entire immersive virtual environments.

Imagine a beach scene complete with dolphins, sand and sun. And imagine, as the human in virtual-reality goggles moving through the scene, being able to smell the salt-air breeze, actively interact with objects in the environment and, who knows, maybe even hitch a lift on a dolphin.

item.title: Comment on Culture splat (a few broad spoilers) by Dzoldzaya
item.description:
In my experience, people in films generally say f***ing more than people in real life, it often seems like a forced attempt to sound “gritty” and “grown-up”. Game of Thrones and “gritty” historical dramas are particularly egregious examples.

HBO: A fantasy show with dragons and magic/ a soap opera about attractive tennis players, won’t people think it’s for kids?
Director : Not if we make them say f*** every few sentences.

item.title: Comment on *Native Nations* by peri
item.description:
I find it very strange that T.C. would accept all this theorizing so unquestioningly.
The population numbers were so low, and I'm not aware that there was much "spread" of anything among the tribes of North America. Certainly language doesn't bear this out, nor building nor farming techniques.
I am completely prepared to defer to her scholarship, though. It's just weird to hear such bold claims as if they were old hat.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/04/native-nations.html?commentID=160750038

Post URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/04/native-nations.html?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=native-nations

Votes: 202⬆ 0⬇
item.dc:creator: peri

item.title: Comment on *Native Nations* by dearieme
item.description:
Compare with the Black Death: population numbers collapsed in Europe but the survivors were better fed. Society recovered.

For the Injuns it was rotten luck that the soon to be prevalent epidemics were brought by people from the Old World who were themselves an additional source of heavy pressure. Though, to be fair, they were also a source for the horses that transformed the prosperity of the Plains Indians.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/04/native-nations.html?commentID=160749999

Post URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/04/native-nations.html?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=native-nations

Votes: 244⬆ 2⬇
item.dc:creator: dearieme

item.title: Comment on *Native Nations* by Ricardo
item.description:
Any rapid change in predictable patterns of rainfall, seasonality and temperature seems bad. Drought is bad for obvious reasons and so is too much rain at once, which can destroy crops. Temperatures that are either too low or too high for a given season can also lower yields or destroy crops. In coastal communities, changes in ocean temperature can change the types of fish or sea creatures available for catching and warmer ocean temperatures can whip up stronger hurricanes/typhoons.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/04/native-nations.html?commentID=160749947

Post URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/04/native-nations.html?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=native-nations

Votes: 246⬆ 2⬇

item.title: Comment on *Native Nations* by Brett
item.description:
Without horses and the like, they didn’t really have the means or pressure to go back to wide scale consolidation and political centralization. Although it never went away in Central America.
